On 2/20/11 12:47 AM, Mahmoud Mubarak wrote:
>
> How can I crawl any flash videos?
>
> The used extractor queue:
>
> <bean id="extractorHttp" class="org.archive.modules.extractor.ExtractorHTTP">   </bean>
> <bean id="extractorHtml" class="org.archive.modules.extractor.ExtractorHTML">   </bean>
> <bean id="extractorCss" class="org.archive.modules.extractor.ExtractorCSS">   </bean>
> <bean id="extractorJs" class="org.archive.modules.extractor.ExtractorJS">   </bean>
> <bean id="extractorSwf" class="org.archive.modules.extractor.ExtractorSWF">   </bean>
>

There's not yet a surefire technique for all situations.

For some sites which use HTTP to fetch a discrete FLV-format video 
resource, the HTML extractor may find the actual URL to the FLV video in 
the embedding parameters.

However, even sites using HTTP to fetch FLV may only compose that URL 
dynamically, inside the SWF player code. Our ExtractorSWF can find 
static outlink URLs from SWF resources, but not dynamically-composed URLs.

Sometimes the formulas for creating these URLs are predictable, and then 
either the ExtractorImpliedURI or some custom script code (via the 
ScriptedProcessor) can be configured, with effort, to auto-generate a 
candidate outlink URI from either the source URI, or one of the 
triggering outlink URIs found another way.

However, these hand-crafted rules tend to decay rapidly -- many of the 
sites that dynamically compose FLV URLs are regularly changing the form 
of final URLs, perhaps even to thwart automated collection.

Another technique is to ask a full web browser, under remote control, to 
visit candidate pages and then observe the URLs it requests -- for 
example by sending all its requests through a web proxy. (The proxy 
could record to WARCs, or share the discovered URL lists with another 
crawler.)

Tools for performing web app unit tests with browsers (such as Selenium) 
or for creating scriptable/'headless' browsers (like 'Crowbar' or 
QT-WebKit) can prove helpful here. We've used this technique for a QA 
tool that's called 'Browser Monkeys' and other ad hoc crawling, but not 
yet integrated these things into the Heritrix codebase.

Also, the above techiques are limited to discovering full videos that 
are fetched as HTTP. Streamed video over other protocols (as sometimes 
also seen in Flash video playback) requires different techniques.

Some projects have had success detecting candidate streams during a 
normal Heritrix crawl, but then offloading stream-requests to the 
'mplayer' tool on Linux, which can dump the retrieved video to a file. 
The paper by Nicholas Baly in the IWAW'06 proceedings gave an overview 
of this general technique at that time:

http://iwaw.europarchive.org/06/

I believe other European archiving efforts have updated Baly's work to 
archive various audio/video streams on an ongoing basis... anyone have 
more details?

- Gordon @ IA
